story:
I would like to start this off with a "thank you" for taking the time to learn about me, my goals, and my eventual dream.

After earning a degree in Graphic Design in college, I moved to San Diego in November of 2013 to expand my horizons and look for opportunties. They have been few and far between. I am working, but not in a field I want to be in for the long term. My trouble is, in my line of work unless you are with a company that has an actual focus in graphic design, you are a sub-contractor/free lance artist. Without proper platforms to share my work and expertise with potential clients, it makes finding/maintaining a legitimate career difficult.

That is where YOU come in.

 


I have a freelance Graphic design business I started last year. It is yet to take off. The reason I need your help is because I have developed an app through Como that will allow potential clients to have more access to me and my design work. However, Como does require a monthly plan in other for me to get my app to the Google store where people will have access to it.  At this time I can't afford that monthly plan. Your donation that will afford me the chance to get my app out for a year ($500). This gives me a priceless opportunity to build up and streamline a workflow and client list.


Follow the link below, you will be able to see my full functioning android app, my cost, and be able to evaluate it's usefulness in helping me continue to pursue my career. Your donation will also go toward helping me create this app for the Iphone platform.

http://www.uzodesign.com/miscellaneous.html

Here's a link to view and download the app

Thank you for your support.

Sincerely,

Uzoma Albert

PS: If you need design work don't hesitate to contact Uzo Design.

story:
DockCase Adapter for MacBook Series

 

 

 

 

 

 

Frustrated of living in a dongle hell with USB-C MacBook system? Bothered by not having enough space in your bag for the flood of adapters and chargers? You may need a one-stop solution for all these problems, rather than a compromising choice of a USB-C hub and a multiport charger. Versatile. Portable. Compact. DockCase Adapter will be the one solution to fix all problems.

 

 

 

With the new MacBook series’ short battery life, we always have to carry the power adapter around anyway. How about solving the docking problem based on the original charger? We created a charger-based dock by building an embedded USB-C male connector in a protective case, and designing an L-shaped notch to make the plug retain detachable within the case. It enables your MacBook / Air / Pro's charger to work as a docking and charging station simultaneously, without adding too much space and weight. This is the most portable way to carry a dock with you, when it becomes a part of your power adapter.

  

 

Specifically Designed for MacBook Series

 

Dock and Charge Your MacBook/Air/Pro Simultaneously

When DockCase Adapter assembled with the original charger and connected to a power source, it will charge your laptop when you use it as a dock in the meantime. It will never happen again that your computer died when syncing data.  

 

Charge Multiple Devices from One Outlet

Leave the mountain of power adapters at home and charge your laptop, iPad Pro 2018, iPhone, tablet, and other devices all by one adapter.  DockCase Adapter can simultaneously charge your USB-C MacBook series and up to 4 USB devices at fast speed. With the QC port, you can charge your quick charge devices up to 3X faster than standard chargers. The MC (multiport charger) version can multiport your charger, which perfectly satisfy the charging needs for your mobile devices on the go. And it has been simplified for charging only with data transfer function reduced, but you can have it with a pledge starts from $15.

 

Switch AC Plug without Removing the Case

DockCase Adapter retains the modular and expandable feature of the power adapter by leaving the plug head part unwrapped. Your power adapter can still perfectly work with AC plugs or Apple power adapter extension cable. And it’s convenient to change the plug head without removing DockCase Adapter - great choice for international travelers.

 

Support 4K HDMI Display

DockCase Adapter HD version supports up to 4K HDMI data transmission, therefore, you can connect your MacBook, Air or Pro to a TV, monitor or projector through the HDMI port and enjoy your favorite shows and movies with magnificent image quality and color.  

  

Ultra-Portable and Space-Saving

With the unique adapter-casing design, DockCase Adapter merely adds small volume based on the adapter. It saves more space for your other devices and belongings. As it encases your adapter, there is no chance to forget it at home as long as you take the power adapter itself.

 

Perfect Replacement with Minimum Cost

 

With a pledge of $30, you can get DockCase Adapter, which can work as a docking station and a multiport charger. No need to waste your money on expensive hubs or dongles. DockCase Adapter will take over all work.

 

 

 

Indiegogo Special

 

 

Early Bird

 

 

Indiegogo Double & Combo

 

 

 

 

 

                                                             

                                                

                                                 

 

 

The following video demonstrated a fully functional pre-production DockCase Adapter with all ports working. (The product tested in the video is HD version for 13-inch MacBook Pro.)

 

 

 

 

 

 

We are a team of engineers and designers motivated by making the lives of Apple users easier and hassle-free. We launched our first Kickstarter campaign, DockCase - The ultimate dock and case for MacBook, in August 2017 and backed by 1,714 people with a total pledge of $148,353. Influential media, including CNET, Business Insider, and Unbox Therapy, recommended our product. And we just conducted another successful Kickstarter campaign "DockCase Adapter for MacBook Pro", which also gained a lot of great feedbacks. Along with the new MacBook Air released, the demanding of the DockCase Adapter for MacBook Air is climbing. And that's why we are here again.

The concept of “less is more” keeps driving us to refine our ideas and techniques to create products more friendly to Apple users. Being through rounds of testing and improvement, DockCase Adapter, an adapter-based USB-C dock for expansion, data transfer mobile device charging, and portable carrying eventually turns to be a satisfied product. Versatile, Apple-style, compact and ultra-portable. It will end up the dongle life of MacBook users. We have reliable suppliers and experienced manufacturers, and ready to introduce DockCase Adapter to the world.

And it’s convenient to change the plug head without removing DockCase Adapter - great choice for international travelers. Support 4K HDMI DisplayDockCase Adapter HD version supports up to 4K HDMI data transmission, therefore, you can connect your MacBook, Air or Pro to a TV, monitor or projector through the HDMI port and enjoy your favorite shows and movies with magnificent image quality and color.    Ultra-Portable and Space-SavingWith the unique adapter-casing design, DockCase Adapter merely adds small volume based on the adapter. It saves more space for your other devices and belongings. As it encases your adapter, there is no chance to forget it at home as long as you take the power adapter itself. Perfect Replacement with Minimum Cost With a pledge of $30, you can get DockCase Adapter, which can work as a docking station and a multiport charger. No need to waste your money on expensive hubs or dongles. DockCase Adapter will take over all work.   Indiegogo Special  Early Bird  Indiegogo Double & Combo                                                                                                                                                                     The following video demonstrated a fully functional pre-production DockCase Adapter with all ports working. (The product tested in the video is HD version for 13-inch MacBook Pro.)

 
     We are a team of engineers and designers motivated by making the lives of Apple users easier and hassle-free. We launched our first Kickstarter campaign, DockCase - The ultimate dock and case for MacBook, in August 2017 and backed by 1,714 people with a total pledge of $148,353. Influential media, including CNET, Business Insider, and Unbox Therapy, recommended our product. And we just conducted another successful Kickstarter campaign "DockCase Adapter for MacBook Pro", which also gained a lot of great feedbacks. Along with the new MacBook Air released, the demanding of the DockCase Adapter for MacBook Air is climbing. And that's why we are here again.The concept of “less is more” keeps driving us to refine our ideas and techniques to create products more friendly to Apple users. Being through rounds of testing and improvement, DockCase Adapter, an adapter-based USB-C dock for expansion, data transfer mobile device charging, and portable carrying eventually turns to be a satisfied product. Versatile, Apple-style, compact and ultra-portable. It will end up the dongle life of MacBook users. We have reliable suppliers and experienced manufacturers, and ready to introduce DockCase Adapter to the world.

story:
What's Parker1?

Parker1 is a low-cost WiFi / 4G mobile robot with vision ability. It runs with two popular open source software, Arduino compatible code for easy robot programming, and OpenWrt router OS for a variety of connectivity over WiFi, 4G etc.

Let the users get playing on Parker1 just with a browser device on hand. Parker1 is preloaded with a basic, in full-function codes. And the source codes would be open on internet, hopefully turns into a community-based support system.

How to Command Parker1 on Play?

The motion control of Parker1 is quite simple. The user opens a browser window and issues the motion control commands (in ASCII char format) to Parker1 via cgi-script. Then OpenWrt passes it as serial data to ATMEGE328, which runs an Arduino serial monitor and executes the motions accordingly.

As the Arduino lovers, you can just focus on Arduino coding upon the commands received from the serial monitor. And it is possible to add-on extra sensors / circuits with the ATMEGA328 IO pinout header on board. The data pass-over by OpenWrt is transparent to you, the preloaded firmware already take care of it. The video streaming is enabled at boot time, just let the users get started with no plain!

If you are familiar with OpenWrt, Parker1 gives you the freedom in network and webcam config customization.

Key Features

  • Atheros AR7240 running OpenWrt with WiFi / 4G connectivity support
  • Atmel ATMEGA328 running Arduino compatible codes
  • Standard USB webcam module for MJPEG capture, and streaming over network by mjpg-streamer plug-in in OpenWrt
  • 2-wheels system plus one servo for tilting, provides all axes of robot and webcam motions
  • Various on-board USB peripheral options (via a USB hub to AR7240)
    • Webcam
    • ATMEGA328 serial port via FTDI FT2332RL
    • micro-SD reader (port sharing with ATMEGA328)
    • USB audio
    • 3G / 4G USB dongle

Hardware Specifications

  • Atheros AR7240 400MHz MIPS-core network processor with 64MB DDR RAM and 16MB SPI flash (firmware storage)
  • Mini-PCIe slot for WiFi / 4G cards, support both full-size / half-size card
  • 1port 10/100M Fast Ethernet (by AR7240 on-chip Eth. Controller)
  • AR7240 console access via FTDI FT2332RL
  • 30.0M USB webcam module
  • 4-port USB hub
  • USB audio
  • micro-SD card reader
  • Type-A USB connector for 3G / 4G USB dongle
  • Atmel ATMEGA328 16MHz micro-controller
  • ATMEGA328 serial port via FTDI FT2332RL (To AR7240 / user-accessible on USB mini-B connector)
  • Toshiba TB6612FNG dual motor driver
  • ATMEGA328 IO pinout header
  • 3-pin header for SG90 servo
  • 2.4G WiFi printed antenna
  • 1300mAH 3.7V Li-ion battery, for 30 minutes system power

3 Configs for WiFi / 4G Connect

What's Included in "Parker1 WiFi Kit"?

“Parker1 WiFi Kit” is first available at launch. The users need “Assembly-It-Yourself” with standard cross screwdriver and pliers.

  • 1pc Parker1 main board
  • 1pc 30.0M USB webcam module with cable and mount accessories  (Currently mjpg-streamer supports 352x288 pixels in our demo.)
  • 2pcs 30mm-Dia. wheels and geared motors, with mount accessories
  • Atheros AR9285 / 9287 1x1 BGN 150M WiFi mini-PCIe half-size card, with full-size extension adopter and RF pigtail for antenna connection
  • 1pc 1300mAH 3.7V Li-ion battery
  • 1pc “USB Type-A to USB Mini-B” cable for PC connection and battery charging

What We're Going on?

We just have developed the first working prototype of Parker1 which we demonstrated in the video.

To bring Parker1 to market and offer it at a low price at launch, we want to raise $35,000 to get Parker1 into first production. We plan to sell Parker1 WiFi kit at retail price of $149 (International shipping included).
Just focus on Parker1 we all wanted, we offer "Parker1 WiFi kit" as a major reward to those backers. And the first production is exclusive for those backers here.

When this crowd funding campaign gets closed, we would start the process of first volume production. It should take within two months. First Customer Shipment is expected in the end of SEP. 

Thanks for your interests and contributions to Parker1 project.

story:
The idea of BLYZZ first came into my mind years ago. Back then technological advancements didn't reach far enough to upload pictures, videos, etc... to a mobile phone. Today using mobile terminal devices this is optimally possible.

DE
Die Idee zu BLYZZ ist mir schon vor Jahren gekommen. Damals war jedoch die Technologie nicht so weit, um Bilder, Videos usw.. auf das Handy zu laden. Doch heute mit den mobilen Endgeräten ist es optimal.

In short: 

The user receives content on her Mobile Phone or Tablet (designed for him personally) which he evaluates, buys or even recommends to other people.

DE
Kurz gesagt:
Der User kriegt Content  auf sein Tablet oder Handy(der für ihn zugeschnitten ist) und er bewertet diesen, bzw. kauft oder empfiehlt ihn sogar weiter. 


Why should a user watch content?


1. He receives a reward onto his internal account immediately after evaluation.

2. He receives content he may like or be interested in

3. There are special actions like coupons or other rewards for the user.

4. He receives additional rewards for recommendations (affiliates) to the              third  downline Level of your invitated Friends.

5.  And we have dayly or weekly Contests for the best Users. And they get               Cash or Coupons. 


6. The more active and the more honest the user handles content (Scoring)        the higher his income is going to be.

DE

Warum sollte ein User sich Content ansehen?

1. Er bekommt dafür unmittelbar nach Bewertung, eine Vergütung auf sein    

     internes Konto gut geschrieben.

2. Er bekommt Content der ihm interessieren und zusagen könnte

3. Es gibt spezielle Aktionen wie Coupons oder Aktionen für den User

4. Und für Weiterempfehlung (Affiliate) erhält er zusätzliche Vergütungen           bis zur dritten Tiefe seiner Freunde.  Die Auszahlungen sind dann am                 Endgerät  (Handy oder Tablet) jederzeit ersichtlich und werden ständig            aktualisiert.

5.  Und es gibt tägliche, wöchentliche und  monatliche Wettbewerbe mit               Barpreise und Gutscheine.

6. Je aktiver und ehrlicher ein User ist, desto mehr Content und Geld wird er        verdienen.

     

Rewards / Vergütungen
Are being accredited online immediately and can be requested via Paypal.
Or eventually can be changed into coupons of advertisers. (for example less expensive for User, etc...)

DE
Werden sofort Online gut geschrieben und können mittels Paypal angefordert werden.

Oder eventuell auch gegentauscht werden in Gutscheine der Werber (zb. etwas günstiger für User, usw...)


SCORING

This is a flexible value that rises and falls depending on the activity of the USER. The better his value the more content he receives in the future and the more he is therefore going to earn.
The lower the value the less content he is going to receive. Can even lead to deactivation.

DE
Bewertung
Dies ist ein flexibler Wert der steigt und fällt, je nach Aktivität des USERS.
Je besser sein Wert, desto mehr Content wird er bekommen und desto mehr wird er dafür erhalten.

Je schlechter der Wert, desto weniger Content wird er erhalten. Kann bis zur Deaktivierung führen.

For Advertisers

For the ADVERTISER a purposeful advertising is formed (TARGET-Marketing, similar to Google). 

There are ways of filtering at the beginning like: Gender, age, country, city and as a result also additional information about the user (which the user specifies in the course of time) like hobbies, preferences, etc...
Using our Scoring the advertiser can also declare that he wants to send content to especially active users.

Here it is of course necessary to elaborate the process of Scoring but also to offer good content. 

Coupons
It is also planned that the user can change parts of his rewards into coupons of the advertisers. Here an additional value for the user should exist.

DE
Werber
Für den WERBER ergibt sich ein ziel gerechtes Werben (TARGET Marketing, ähnlich wie bei Google).

Es gibt Filtermöglichkeiten gleich zu Beginn wie: Geschlecht, Alter, Land, Stadt
Und in Folge dann auch weitere Infos über den User (die der User mit der Zeit angibt) wie zb. Interessen, Vorlieben, usw...

Und durch unser Scoring kann der Werber auch sagen, dass er Content an besonders aktive User senden möchte.

Hier gilt es natürlich dieses Scoringprozess zu verfeinern aber auch guten Content anzubieten.

Gutscheine
Angedacht ist auch, dass der User einen Teil seiner Vergütungen in Gutscheine der Werber tauscht. Hier sollte es jedoch einen zusätzlichen Mehrwert geben für den User.

First App-Designs:
Hier erste APP Entwürfe:

 


Design: internal area
Entwurf interner Bereich:


Login area:
Loginbereich:

Internal area:
Interner Bereich:

As previously said, parts of the system are already developed. Still we want to finalize programming the system completely in order to be able to registrate our first users soon.

DE
Wie gesagt, Teile des Systems sind schon entwickelt. Jedoch möchten wir das System komplett ausprogrammieren, um bald erste User registrieren zu können.


  • What we do with the money
    & What you get 

  • The largest part flows into the software-development by my two developers whereby I have already invested my own money and we have started development in March. 
  • Additional money from the campaign is going to be spent for the USERS in form of constant Contests (here the most active affiliates are rewarded with boni) and for online advertisements.  
  • Should there be more funds coming in they are going to be invested in additional advertisements (Phone-actions to potential customers, external work,...)  and into expanding the webpage 
  • For you as an investor there is the possibility of participating in the success of this idea. (Share Program)  
  • Or you receive special boni and rewards if you log in as user. 
  • The market is huge. Lots of companies pay a number of euros per click using search engines. In case of us the click will be distinctly cheaper (0,5-1,0 €) and much more effective because the advertiser can define his target audience, for example by gender, city, age, interests, etc...(we are going to create a special analyzing software).   
  • The user evaluates the watched content. Also a good indicator for the advertiser!  
  • Of course we are going to try to set filters and will further elaborate the software in order to filter mere "Clicker". We thereby think of a Scoring for every User. 

    DE

  • Für was wir das Geld verwenden & Was ihr dafür bekommt

  • Der größte Teil ist für die Softwareentwicklung meiner beiden Entwickler eingerechnet. Wobei ich bereits eigenes Geld investiert habe und wir mit der Entwicklung im März begonnen haben.
  • Zusätzliches Geld aus der Kampagne werden für die USER in Form von ständigen Contests (Es werden hier die aktivsten Affiliierter mit Prämien belohnt) und für Online Werbung ausgeben.  
  • Sollte darüber hinaus mehr Kapital hereinkommen, werden wir diese für weitere Werbung (Telefonaktion an potentielle Werbekunden, Außendienstmitarbeiter, ...) und in den Ausbau der Seite investieren
  • Für dich als Investor gibt es die Möglichkeit sich am Erfolg der Idee zu beteiligen. (Share Programm)
  • Oder wenn du dich als User anmeldest, bekommst du spezielle Bonis und Vergütungen.
  • Und der User gibt eine Bewertung des gesehenen Contents ab. Auch ein guter Indikator für den Werber!
  • Und der Markt ist riesig. Viele Firmen bezahlen über Suchmaschinen etliche Euro pro Click . Bei uns wird der Click deutlich günstiger sein (bis 0,5 bis 1,0€) und zweitens viel effektiver sein, da der Werber die Zielgruppe definieren kann.
    Zb. nach Geschlecht, Stadt, ca. Alter, Interessen, usw... (wir werden hier eine spezielle Analysesoftware entwickeln.
  •  Wir werden natürlich versuchen Filter zu setzen und die Software zu verfeinern.
  • Um natürlich reine "Clicker" auszufiltern. Wir denken da an ein Scoring für jeden User.


  • Potential of the idea:
    Potential der Idee:

In my opinion inside a multi-digit range of millions. Of course depends on user-numbers and offered content!

DE

Meiner Meinung nach im mehrstelligen Millionenbereich. Hängt natürlich von den Userzahlen und den angebotenen Content ab!


  • But like this in normal CASE
    Aber so im Normal CASE


  • 2014     15.000 User       Advertisement-income per user minimum 50€
                 Thereby a total of 750.000€
                 Reward to the Users up to 50%: 375.000€
    DE
    2014     15.000 User       Werbeumsatz  pro User mindestens 50€ 
                 Gesamt also 750.000€
                 Ausschüttung an die User 50%: 375.000€
  • 2015     30.000 User      Advertisement-income per user min. 100€
                 Thereby a total of 3,0 Mio Euro
                 Reward to the Users up to 50%: 1,5 Mio €
    DE
    2015     30.000 User      Werbeumsatz pro User mind. 100 € 
                  Gesamt also 3,0 Mio Euro
                  Ausschüttung an die User 50%: 1,5 Mio €

  • 2016-18 Duplication planned
    2016-18 Verdoppelung geplant

  • 5 % of total income net go to the investors via the diamond package, for example 2015......... 150.000€
    DE
    5 % vom Gesamtumsatz netto gehen an die Investoren mit dem Diamantpaket. Als Beispiel: Umsatz:   2015....... 5 %  150.000€  
      
    Das wären in dem Fall von 30 Diamant-Unterstützer 15.000€!!             

  • I think using viral marketing and more effective benefits for the advertiser much higher incomes and user-numbers are possible!
    DE
    Ich denke, durch das Viralmarketing und den effektiveren Nutzen für den Werber sind hier viel höhere Umsätze und Userzahlen möglich!
                                                                   
  • For example:
    If you look at numbers of Google, our assumptions are not even in a scope of per mille:

    DE
    Als Beispiel:
    Wenn man sich Zahlen von Google ansieht, dann sind unsere Annahmen nicht einmal im Promillebereich:
    1. Finance & Insurance - $ 4.0 Billion
    2. Retailers & General Merchandise – $2.8 Billion
    3. Travel & Tourism – $2.4 Billion
    4. Jobs & Education – $2.2 Billion
    5. Home & Garden— $2.1 Billion
    6.  Computer & Consumer Electronics – $2.0 Billion
    7. Vehicles – $2.0 Billion
    8. Internet & Telecommunications – $1.7 Billion
    9. Business & Industrial – $1.6 Billion
    10. Occasions & Gifts – $1.2 Billion
    Source: www.wordstream.com

    1. Finance & Insurance - $ 4.0 Milliarden
    2. Retailers & General Merchandise – $2.8 Milliarden
    3. Travel & Tourism – $2.4 Milliarden
    4. Jobs & Education – $2.2 Milliarden
    5. Home & Garden— $2.1 Milliarden
    6.  Computer & Consumer Electronics – $2.0 Milliarden
    7. Vehicles – $2.0 Milliarden
    8. Internet & Telecommunications – $1.7 Milliarden
    9. Business & Industrial – $1.6 Milliarden
    10. Occasions & Gifts – $1.2 Milliarden
    Quelle: www.wordstream.com 

  • Goal:
  • We want to create a worldwide community containing millions of active users which are able to build a financial basis for themselves by evaluating and recommending specific content.

  • DE
  • Ziel ist:
  • Wir wollen eine weltweite Community mit Millionen aktiven Usern aufbauen, die für das Bewerten und Weiterempfehlen von Content sich ein finanzielles Standbein aufbauen können.


We also fix planned to change in a Share Company at 2015 or 2016.


DE

Die Wandlung in Aktiengesellschaft ist außerdem im Jahr 2015-2016 geplant.



To all investors and users: Our page will get online during the next weeks! You can already register in advance.
Registration or download: Blyzz or download the APP later via Google-Shop!

If you have questions feel free to ask me!

Let`s Blyzz

Peter Aldrian


DE

Für alle Investoren und User: Unsere Seite wird in den nächsten Wochen online gehen! Ihr könnt euch jedoch schon vorab registrieren.

Anmeldung, bzw. Download : Blyzz oder später im Google-Shop den APP downloaden!



Bei Fragen stehe ich gerne zur Verfügung!

Let`s Blyzz

Peter Aldrian

What we do with the money & What you get 

The largest part flows into the software-development by my two developers whereby I have already invested my own money and we have started development in March. 

Additional money from the campaign is going to be spent for the USERS in form of constant Contests (here the most active affiliates are rewarded with boni) and for online advertisements.  
Should there be more funds coming in they are going to be invested in additional advertisements (Phone-actions to potential customers, external work,...)  and into expanding the webpage 

For you as an investor there is the possibility of participating in the success of this idea. (Share Program)  

Or you receive special boni and rewards if you log in as user. 
The market is huge. Lots of companies pay a number of euros per click using search engines. The user evaluates the watched content. Also a good indicator for the advertiser!

Alter, Interessen, usw... (wir werden hier eine spezielle Analysesoftware entwickeln.

story:
Purpose

This campaign is to raise funds to purchase new SSD drives to improve the WbSrch search engine.

WbSrch is a project that I started a little over two years ago, after AltaVista shut down. It's online and running, but it's pretty early-stage.

Why Build a Search Engine?

Almost all of the search engine competition has been shut down or acquired and killed. Blekko, Cuil, AltaVista, and many others no longer exist.

Most other sites claiming to be search engines are just front-ends to Bing or Google results and aren't adding anything of their own.

There isn't enough competition in search and it's a problem.

If you run a website or a web-based business you probably live in constant fear of angering Google. If it decides it doesn't like you, you're pretty much done. Close your business, send everyone home, and move on to something else. You won't get any traffic or any customers if the gateway to the world's information closes its doors on you.

There was a time when there was enough competition in search that if one engine didn't like you and one loved you things would balance out. Now there is effectively only one, Google. Bing has been accused of copying Google, so that's not exactly diversity.

A few competitors exist, but most don't make a dent in English-language search: DuckDuckGo, Yandex, Gigablast, Exalead, and some others you've never heard of.

The goal is to become a viable alternative, at least at the same level as DuckDuckGo. They have a head start,  since WbSrch is 5 years younger than the youngest one on that list, DuckDuckGo, but we're catching up fast.

The Team

So far this is mostly just a one-person show run from Portland, OR. My LinkedIn page should give a decent overview of my background. My wife Suzanne has been contributing design, ideas, and testing help and my friend and former startup cofounder Lindsay created the how-to-use video and has offered some marketing help.

If you know things about search engines and information retrieval, we should be friends, even if we don't end up working together. This project will eventually need more people.

I like to use "we" when talking about WbSrch because it won't always be a mostly-one-person operation.

Where We Are Now

I built a custom crawler and indexer for WbSrch. It has a small database right now, not much more than 13.5 million pages, and the engine is still pretty young. However, over the course of 2015, the database grew by more than 60%. This year I'd like to get to 50 million pages. That's nearly 4x larger -- and it's doable with a hardware upgrade.

OK, now take a break and go search for something on wbsrch.com. You can check out the video for more details about basic usage, but it works just like any other search engine you've used. Try a few searches.

Back? I bet the results weren't awesome. But unlike most other search engines pitching for crowdfunding, we do have something up, online, and working. It's not great yet. But it's making significant forward progress every month (just check out our changelog). This is only a part-time project. I'd love to be able to work on this for a living, but there's a lot more to do before I can consider that. It's a big journey. And no, WbSrch is not a Google killer. Don't be silly.

WbSrch does some things well, and other things not so well. At this point it's about as good as your average mid-to-late-1990s search engine.

We get about 500 or so searches per day from real people, and another 4x that from bots pretending to be people (the stealth bots love us). Traffic has been doubling every 3 months so far.

Privacy

WbSrch is better than Bing and Google in the privacy department. It doesn't use tracking cookies at all. It logs what requests came from what IP (the same as any typical web server), mostly for blocking spambots, and there's no way to tie a search back to an individual computer or user (an IP address is not a person).

We don't build user profiles of any kind; neither do we provide forced "customized" search results (known as "filter bubbles"). And we don't want to.

The Software

I built everything with Python and PostgreSQL. I use the Django framework heavily, as well as SQLAlchemy. It all runs on Linux with an NGINX web server.

Yes, many people call Python slow. That's not the bottleneck here. Our bottleneck is disk I/O speed. Once we've read the data we're going to process, processing it is fast. I wish Python was the slow part because I know C++ (and C) very well and could do a great job rewriting the slow parts. Nope -- the processors are generally pretty bored most of the time. That will gradually change as we get more and more data to process, but it won't be this year.

It's pretty common for an indexing task to take 60 seconds to read the data it needs and then 2 seconds to process it. If read time becomes 6 seconds (10x faster), things become very different.

Hosting

We do not use cloud hosting. Cloud hosting companies make their money on RAM, and we have a pretty RAM-intensive system. We'd be paying more than $1200 per month for what we use. And, of course, you're at their mercy if they think you're doing something that looks fishy or too bot-like. You know, like crawling the web. And, of course, lots of sites block access from Amazon EC2 IP addresses. (I don't know whether stackoverflow.com still does, but it did.)

WbSrch runs in a local colocation facility. Hosting costs about $140 per month for 3 dedicated servers (a 5U rack space).

We've bought a few secondhand HP servers from eBay, things that have just gone off-lease and are a good deal. Servers haven't gotten much faster in the past few years (with the exception of SSDs), so we're not suffering too much by using older hardware. Except for the drives.

Our current hardware setup (skip this section if you don't care about technical details):

Index Server -- Contains indexed terms and phrases, along with search metadata.

It's an HP DL360 G6 with 24GB of RAM, dual Xeon L5630 processors (8 cores total), and 4 300GB SAS drives in RAID 10.

It has fairly light load and we could quadruple in size before needing to upgrade. The processors are mostly asleep and disks do most of the work. It has some empty RAM slots, and RAM is cheap, so doubling the RAM would reduce disk load inexpensively (if you can spare PC3-10600R server memory in 4GB or larger modules, please send it our way). And upgrading to 4x 1TB SSDs would make this able to handle growth (in both load and index size) to around 30x what we have now.

Data is split up in such a way that this would be easy to separate into multiple servers as traffic increases.

Crawl Server -- Contains pending URLs to be crawled along with page link data.

It's an HP DL160 G6 with 72GB of RAM, dual Xeon L5530 processors (8 cores total), and 4 1TB SATA drives in RAID 10.

This keeps track of URLs. There are a LOT of them, but you don't ever need to access all of them at once, so disk space is more important than speed. It has more RAM than it really needs, so I could always take some from this and move it into the index server if necessary.

This could handle about 6x growth without needing to think about any kind of hardware upgrades. The disks are REALLY slow. This was the first standalone WbSrch server (in 2014), and it just couldn't keep up very well (and that was before we added a RAID controller). Now that it's just adding and removing URLs from a pile a handful at a time, it keeps up just fine.

Page Database Server and Indexer -- This is the machine that does most of the work. It keeps crawled pages and generates index data from them.

It's an HP DL180 G6 with 96GB of RAM, dual Xeon L5639 processors (12 cores total), and 8 143GB SAS drives in RAID 10.

The disks are pretty much always pegged at 100% utilization. It can never use all of its CPU cores at once because it's waiting on disk I/O. A RAM upgrade would help, but all RAM slots are filled with 8GB modules, and there's a price jump when upgrading to 16GB modules (though prices have come down a bit lately).

Early in 2015, this was set up with a 6-disk RAID 10 array of 240GB Mushkin Chronos SSDs, the cheapest SSDs you could buy at the time. It was super fast and performed very well for about 4 months. Then 3 drives failed in rapid succession and I had to go back to 143GB SAS drives. Lost all the data on the drives, but I had a backup, so only lost about a month of crawling (luckily no code was lost -- hooray for source control).

By the end of 2016, generation 8 HP Proliant hardware should be pretty cheap, so that might be the right time for more upgrades. Dell has a pretty similar power-to-cost ratio.

How You Can Help

The biggest way you can help is to contribute to this IndieGoGo campaign.

We'd also love donations of hardware -- maybe your company is retiring some servers and you'd like to help keep them out of the landfill. A 3-year-old ProLiant or PowerEdge that your company has decommissioned in favor of new hardware and might just leave sitting in a warehouse is pure gold to us.

You can also help by using the search engine. The way it's built, it gets better as people search for things. Search for yourself, the sites you care about, your hobbies. Things like that will help teach it what's important and worth keeping track of. We'll learn where we have topic shortages, what kind of things we need to add, and what kinds of searches respond too slowly.

Add us to your browser as another search engine. Maybe we're not ready to be your main search engine yet, but you could always try us to get a second opinion when you're not finding what you want in Google or Bing. Or you can just compare results for fun.

Follow us on Twitter or Facebook so you can keep an eye on our progress.

If you know another language, check out that language-specific index, like fi.wbsrch.com for Finnish. If you can help translate any of the text on one of those sites, send us an email. The translations we do have are mostly from dictionaries and not by native speakers (I have a big pile of dictionaries, in dozens of languages, but only have native-level fluency in one).

If you have a website, a blog, or any other web presence, we'd appreciate a mention or a link. Talk about us. Compare us to other search engines, favorably or not (good reviews attract new users, bad users help us improve). Show us to your friends.

If there's something you want or don't want in a search engine, or if there's some killer feature that would make you switch away from your current search engine, please let me know.

What's the money for?

The biggest thing holding growth back is disk speed. Upgrading to SSD drives will allow us to grow, improve, and iterate faster. A proper upgrade isn't extremely expensive, but it's expensive enough to ask for help.

That's what this IndieGoGo campaign is for – to get some big, fast SSD drives. The Samsung 850 Pro drives have the right mix of speed and reliability. The goal is to buy 13. That's 12 drives in a RAID 10 configuration with one live spare.

This is not a funded company. We don't have VC backing. We're not in an incubator or accelerator. All of these thing have certain strings attached, namely that you're expected to go public or be bought by a big company at some point.

In other words, we are part of the Indie Web, and we want to stay that way as long as possible.

I've spent about $9000 so far on hardware and hosting over the past two years, and it's gone a long way. A contribution to this campaign will also go a long way and make a big difference.

Risks

Not meeting our goal isn't a showstopper. It'll just take a lot longer to improve. We'll eventually upgrade; it'll just take longer to save up.

Because of this, there's no risk in contributing – every dollar helps us increase velocity. It's just a question of how fast we get better.

I wrote an article about crowdfunding search engines a while back. Nobody had yet raised crowdfunding for a search engine successfully when that was written. But almost nobody has had a working prototype, any particular programming skill, or even a reasonable pitch ("I'm going to kill Google" is not a sensible pitch). This will be different. There's a plan, a goal, and existing progress.

Related Mission #1: A Web Browser

We have an early version of a browser called WbBrowse. It's another multiplatform webkit-based browser similar to Chrome or Opera. The goal is to build something more like to Firefox before its interface went into decline.

Every major search engine has its own browser. It's smart -- it's one of the best ways to be discovered by new users. I don't think this will become a major browser, but if it ends up with even a few thousand regular users it'll be worth it.

Grab a copy at wbbrowse.com. It's not first-tier yet, but let me know what it'd need to do to be your secondary browser, if not your primary.

The Windows and Linux versions work reasonably well. The OSX version "works on my machine" and will hopefully become available during this crowdfunding campaign. App Store permitting, of course.

Related Mission #2: An API

WbSrch.com is just one way to present our web crawl data and algorithms. With an API we'll enable other people to build a meta-search site or app that includes our results, build search into an app, or even create your own search engine with what you believe is the One True User Interface.

Related Mission #3: News Search

We could watch selected news sites and update them more frequently than other sites. We'll do this at some point, but it's non-trivial to build.

We have designed it, though, and it's a pretty solid design (I say this not having built it yet -- no design survives contact with reality).

This will require a separate server to set up, but nothing particularly powerful.

Related Mission #4: SEO and Competitive Intelligence Tools

If you have a lot of data about the web, you can give people some useful information.

Think about all of the backlink profiling/checking tools, SEO tools, keyword tools, competitor research, technology research tools like Moz, OpenLinkProfiler, BuiltWith, and the like.

We already have a little part of that available on our domain details pages -- you can see basic information about link popularity, age, and what keywords a domain ranks for. We'd like to expand that and make it more useful. I'm thinking of making this a freemium service - with the premium at a significantly lower price than moz.com charges.

Related Missions #5: Advertising Platform

Nothing can run forever for free (WbSrch costs at least $140 a month to run). One of the things we're building is an advertising platform similar to Project Wonderful (they do ads, but they do them well and aren't annoying about it). You can always use an ad blocker, but I think you can do advertising without being that annoying  (Rule 1: No flash, animated, autoplay audio/video ads, Rule 2: No popups, pop-overs, or pop-unders). Yes, I know you make less money without being annoying.

I also don't like the idea of bidding to change your search position and would like to avoid having that be a thing. It might be inevitable and unavoidable, but I hope not.

We've tried some other advertising providers. One went out of business (it paid badly anyhow). But most providers, including AdSense, don't let you participate if you include links to gambling, porn, drugs, etc. Those are things we deemphasize or exclude based on our content policy, but including links to things ad networks don't like is inevitable.

There are a lot more options in advertising when you get up over the 1 million page views per month mark, so even if we don't have our own ad system, we'll have options. But it's better to control your own destiny if you can, and that's part of the long-term plan.

Long-Term Goal

I'd like to be able to eventually turn this into a small company, a business with between 12 and 20 employees. It could be bigger or smaller, but that seems like a good size.

It might be possible to bootstrap/crowdstrap to that point, but I expect to have to raise funds at some point. If you're a potential investor who is interested in keeping an eye on the project, please get in touch.

This search engine isn't going to defeat Google, or Bing. We just want to develop a solid core of returning users who like the way we do things. In fact, where DuckDuckGo is right now would be a great place to be -- 300 million searches per month. We're at less than 0.01% of that right now and have plenty of work to do to get there. If we get over about 2 million searches per month, I can do this for a living instead of a life-consuming hobby. At 5 million per month I can start hiring people to help. Job creation is good, right?

Stretch Goals

This $3000 campaign will take us to the end of 2016 by allowing us to purchase enough SSDs to get a little bit over a 50-million URL index (4x current size).

There are also $2000 worth of RAM and CPU upgrades that would make a significant difference.

Beyond that, there's the epic "1 billion URL" goal. Building an index of a billion pages is a massive undertaking. We plan to get there someday, but it won't be fast or cheap. And building something that big isn't a one-person task. Beyond that, it doesn't matter what you build if nobody uses it, so we'll need people and resources to promote it and let the world know it exists.

The extreme stretch goal is to acquire Yahoo!. If this campaign raises enough money for an acquisition, they're moving to Portland.

Non-Goals

We don't want to build a video hosting site like YouTube or Vimeo.

We don't want to host email.

We don't want to create an online equivalent to Microsoft Office.

We don't want to create a social network. In fact, our index generally deemphasizes social media sites.

We don't want to create a mobile operating system or an app ecosystem.

We don't want to invent the self-driving food cart.

Undecided Goals

Maps - I've tried some experiments with OpenStreetMap data and some of the related tools/frameworks. It's been interesting, but I'm not sure whether it's worth doing. The hardest part would be getting reliable business-website-to-address mapping/scraping working. Do you want your search engine to include maps? Let me know.

Shopping Search - It seems pretty unnecessary. But the existing ones tend to be not very good. It seems like there are fewer online shops than there were a dozen years ago. Maybe Amazon killed them all, and maybe comparison shopping just isn't a good idea -- it only seems to keep a handful of least-expensive stores happy.

Video Search - We don't want to do video-specific search. *Well, maybe we would, but it would involve restricting to a handful of sites (YouTube, Vimeo, etc.) There aren't really that many video sites left now that YouTube defeated them all. Do you want video-specific search? Let me know.

Image Search - We don't want to do image search. Not without some really good filtering and categorization code. It wouldn't be great to have every keyword you search for turn up nothing but a wall of butts.

For anything visual, filtering out the "what has been seen cannot be unseen" stuff is a HUGE task that would require a lot more people to accomplish effectively. Maybe we'll do it someday, but it's definitely not a near-term goal.

Audio Search - I've thought about this, and though it's interesting, I'd want to do it without including torrent search. Torrent search is very problematic. Just ask ISOHunt and similar sites. I don't want to go there.

"Stumbling" - I've always loved the discovery aspect of sites like StumbleUpon. I'm not yet sure how I'd be able to put an interesting spin on it, though. And, without categorization, you run into the "wall of butts" problem again. We'll eventually have to get decent machine-learning-based categorization figured out, but I'd rather do this later -- after we get regular search working pretty well.

It all runs on Linux with an NGINX web server.Yes, many people call Python slow. That's not the bottleneck here. Our bottleneck is disk I/O speed. Once we've read the data we're going to process, processing it is fast. I wish Python was the slow part because I know C++ (and C) very well and could do a great job rewriting the slow parts. Nope -- the processors are generally pretty bored most of the time. That will gradually change as we get more and more data to process, but it won't be this year.It's pretty common for an indexing task to take 60 seconds to read the data it needs and then 2 seconds to process it. If read time becomes 6 seconds (10x faster), things become very different.HostingWe do not use cloud hosting. Cloud hosting companies make their money on RAM, and we have a pretty RAM-intensive system. We'd be paying more than $1200 per month for what we use. And, of course, you're at their mercy if they think you're doing something that looks fishy or too bot-like. You know, like crawling the web. And, of course, lots of sites block access from Amazon EC2 IP addresses. (I don't know whether stackoverflow.com still does, but it did.)WbSrch runs in a local colocation facility. Hosting costs about $140 per month for 3 dedicated servers (a 5U rack space).We've bought a few secondhand HP servers from eBay, things that have just gone off-lease and are a good deal. Servers haven't gotten much faster in the past few years (with the exception of SSDs), so we're not suffering too much by using older hardware. Except for the drives.Our current hardware setup (skip this section if you don't care about technical details):Index Server -- Contains indexed terms and phrases, along with search metadata. It's an HP DL360 G6 with 24GB of RAM, dual Xeon L5630 processors (8 cores total), and 4 300GB SAS drives in RAID 10. It has fairly light load and we could quadruple in size before needing to upgrade. The processors are mostly asleep and disks do most of the work. It has some empty RAM slots, and RAM is cheap, so doubling the RAM would reduce disk load inexpensively (if you can spare PC3-10600R server memory in 4GB or larger modules, please send it our way). And upgrading to 4x 1TB SSDs would make this able to handle growth (in both load and index size) to around 30x what we have now.Data is split up in such a way that this would be easy to separate into multiple servers as traffic increases.Crawl Server -- Contains pending URLs to be crawled along with page link data.It's an HP DL160 G6 with 72GB of RAM, dual Xeon L5530 processors (8 cores total), and 4 1TB SATA drives in RAID 10.This keeps track of URLs. There are a LOT of them, but you don't ever need to access all of them at once, so disk space is more important than speed. It has more RAM than it really needs, so I could always take some from this and move it into the index server if necessary.This could handle about 6x growth without needing to think about any kind of hardware upgrades. The disks are REALLY slow. This was the first standalone WbSrch server (in 2014), and it just couldn't keep up very well (and that was before we added a RAID controller). Now that it's just adding and removing URLs from a pile a handful at a time, it keeps up just fine.Page Database Server and Indexer -- This is the machine that does most of the work. It keeps crawled pages and generates index data from them.It's an HP DL180 G6 with 96GB of RAM, dual Xeon L5639 processors (12 cores total), and 8 143GB SAS drives in RAID 10.The disks are pretty much always pegged at 100% utilization. It can never use all of its CPU cores at once because it's waiting on disk I/O. A RAM upgrade would help, but all RAM slots are filled with 8GB modules, and there's a price jump when upgrading to 16GB modules (though prices have come down a bit lately).Early in 2015, this was set up with a 6-disk RAID 10 array of 240GB Mushkin Chronos SSDs, the cheapest SSDs you could buy at the time. It was super fast and performed very well for about 4 months. Then 3 drives failed in rapid succession and I had to go back to 143GB SAS drives. Lost all the data on the drives, but I had a backup, so only lost about a month of crawling (luckily no code was lost -- hooray for source control).By the end of 2016, generation 8 HP Proliant hardware should be pretty cheap, so that might be the right time for more upgrades. Dell has a pretty similar power-to-cost ratio.How You Can HelpThe biggest way you can help is to contribute to this IndieGoGo campaign. We'd also love donations of hardware -- maybe your company is retiring some servers and you'd like to help keep them out of the landfill. A
3-year-old ProLiant or PowerEdge that your company has decommissioned
in favor of new hardware and might just leave sitting in a warehouse
is pure gold to us.You can also help by using the search engine. The way it's built, it gets better as people search for things. Search for yourself, the sites you care about, your hobbies. Things like that will help teach it what's important and worth keeping track of. We'll learn where we have topic shortages, what kind of things we need to add, and what kinds of searches respond too slowly.Add us to your browser as another search engine. Maybe we're not ready to be your main search engine yet, but you could always try us to get a second opinion when you're not finding what you want in Google or Bing. Or you can just compare results for fun.Follow us on Twitter or Facebook so you can keep an eye on our progress.If you know another language, check out that language-specific index, like fi.wbsrch.com for Finnish. If you can help translate any of the text on one of those sites, send us an email. The translations we do have are mostly from dictionaries and not by native speakers (I have a big pile of dictionaries, in dozens of languages, but only have native-level fluency in one).If you have a website, a blog, or any other web presence, we'd appreciate a mention or a link. Talk about us. Compare us to other search engines, favorably or not (good reviews attract new users, bad users help us improve). Show us to your friends.If there's something you want or don't want in a search engine, or if there's some killer feature that would make you switch away from your current search engine, please let me know.

What's the money for?The biggest thing holding growth back is disk speed. Upgrading to SSD drives will allow us to grow, improve, and iterate faster. A proper upgrade isn't extremely expensive, but it's expensive enough to ask for help.

That's what this
IndieGoGo campaign is for – to get some big, fast SSD drives. The Samsung 850 Pro drives have the right mix of speed and reliability. The goal is to buy 13. That's 12 drives in a RAID 10 configuration with one live spare.This is not a funded
company. We don't have VC backing. We're not in an incubator or
accelerator. All of these thing have certain strings attached, namely
that you're expected to go public or be bought by a big company at
some point.

In other words, we
are part of the Indie Web, and we want to stay that way as long as possible.I've spent about $9000 so far on hardware and hosting over the past two years, and it's gone a long way. A contribution to this campaign will also go a long way and make a big difference.

RisksNot meeting our goal
isn't a showstopper. It'll just take a lot longer to improve. We'll eventually upgrade; it'll just take longer to save up.Because of this,
there's no risk in contributing – every dollar helps us increase
velocity. It's just a question of how fast we get better.I wrote an article about crowdfunding search engines a while back.
 Nobody had yet raised crowdfunding for a search engine successfully when that was written. But almost nobody has
 had a working prototype, any particular programming skill, or even a 
reasonable pitch ("I'm going to kill Google" is not a sensible pitch). This 
will be different. There's a plan, a goal, and existing progress.Related Mission #1: A Web BrowserWe have an early 
version of a browser called WbBrowse. It's another multiplatform 
webkit-based browser similar to Chrome or Opera. The goal is to build 
something more like to Firefox before its interface went into decline.Every
 major search engine has its own browser. It's smart -- it's one of the 
best ways to be discovered by new users. I don't think this will become a major
 browser, but if it ends up with even a few thousand regular users it'll
 be worth it.Grab a copy at wbbrowse.com. It's not first-tier yet, but let me know what it'd need to do to be your secondary browser, if not your primary.The
 Windows and Linux versions work reasonably well. The OSX version "works on my machine" and will hopefully become available during this crowdfunding campaign. App Store permitting, of course.Related Mission #2: An APIWbSrch.com is just one way to present our web crawl data and algorithms. With an API we'll enable other people to build a meta-search site or app that includes our results, build search into an app, or even create your own search engine with what you believe is the One True User Interface.Related Mission #3: News SearchWe could watch selected news sites and update 
them more frequently than other sites. We'll do this at some point, but it's 
non-trivial to build.We have designed it, though, and it's a pretty solid design (I say this not having built it yet -- no design survives contact with reality).This will require a separate server to set up, but nothing particularly powerful.Related Mission #4: SEO and Competitive Intelligence ToolsIf you have a lot of data about the web, you can give people some useful information.Think
 about all of the backlink profiling/checking tools, SEO tools, 
keyword tools, competitor research, technology research tools like Moz, 
OpenLinkProfiler, BuiltWith, and the like.We already have a 
little part of that available on our domain details pages -- you can see basic 
information about link popularity, age, and what keywords a domain ranks for.
 We'd like to expand that and make it more useful. I'm thinking of making this a freemium service - with the premium at a significantly lower price than moz.com charges.Related Missions #5: Advertising PlatformNothing can run forever for free (WbSrch costs at least $140 a month to run). One of the things we're building is an advertising platform similar to Project Wonderful (they do ads, but they do them well and aren't annoying about it). You can always use an ad blocker, but I think you can do advertising without being that annoying  (Rule 1: No flash, animated, autoplay audio/video ads, Rule 2: No popups, pop-overs, or pop-unders). Yes, I know you make less money without being annoying.I also don't like the idea of bidding to change your search position and would like to avoid having that be a thing. It might be inevitable and unavoidable, but I hope not.We've tried some other advertising providers. One went out of business (it paid badly anyhow). But most providers, including AdSense, don't let you participate if you include links to gambling, porn, drugs, etc. Those are things we deemphasize or exclude based on our content policy, but including links to things ad networks don't like is inevitable.There are a lot more options in advertising when you get up over the 1 million page views per month mark, so even if we don't have our own ad system, we'll have options. But it's better to control your own destiny if you can, and that's part of the long-term plan.Long-Term GoalI'd like to be able to eventually turn this into a small company, a business with between 12 and 20 employees. It could be bigger or smaller, but that seems like a good size.It might be possible to bootstrap/crowdstrap to that point, but I expect to have to raise funds at some point. If you're a potential investor who is interested in keeping an eye on the project, please get in touch.This search engine isn't going to defeat Google, or Bing. We just want to develop a solid core of returning users who like the way we do things. In fact, where DuckDuckGo is right now would be a great place to be -- 300 million searches per month. We're at less than 0.01% of that right now and have plenty of work to do to get there. If we get over about 2 million searches per month, I can do this for a living instead of a life-consuming hobby. At 5 million per month I can start hiring people to help. Job creation is good, right?Stretch GoalsThis $3000 campaign will take us to the end of 2016 by allowing us to purchase enough SSDs to get a little bit over a 50-million URL index (4x current size).There are also $2000 worth of RAM and CPU upgrades that would make a significant difference.Beyond that, there's the epic "1 billion URL" goal. Building an index of a billion pages is a massive undertaking. We plan to get there someday, but it won't be fast or cheap. And building something that big isn't a one-person task. Beyond that, it doesn't matter what you build if nobody uses it, so we'll need people and resources to promote it and let the world know it exists.The extreme stretch goal is to acquire Yahoo!. If this campaign raises enough money for an acquisition, they're moving to Portland.Non-GoalsWe don't want to build a video hosting site like YouTube or Vimeo. We don't want to host email.We don't want to create an online equivalent to Microsoft Office.We don't want to create a social network. In fact, our index generally deemphasizes social media sites.We don't want to create a mobile operating system or an app ecosystem.We don't want to invent the self-driving food cart.Undecided GoalsMaps - I've tried some experiments with OpenStreetMap data and some of the related tools/frameworks. It's been interesting, but I'm not sure whether it's worth doing. The hardest part would be getting reliable business-website-to-address mapping/scraping working. Do you want your search engine to include maps? Let me know.Shopping Search - It seems pretty unnecessary. But the existing ones tend to be not very good. It seems like there are fewer online shops than there were a dozen years ago. Maybe Amazon killed them all, and maybe comparison shopping just isn't a good idea -- it only seems to keep a handful of least-expensive stores happy.

Video Search - We don't want to do video-specific search. *Well, maybe we would, but it
 would involve restricting to a handful of sites (YouTube, Vimeo, etc.) 
There aren't really that many video sites left now that YouTube defeated
 them all. Do you want video-specific search? Let me know.Image Search - We don't want to do image search. Not without some really good filtering and categorization code. It wouldn't be great to have every keyword you search for turn up nothing but a wall of butts.For anything visual, filtering out the "what has been seen cannot be
 unseen" stuff is a HUGE task that would require a lot more people to 
accomplish effectively. Maybe we'll do it someday, but it's definitely not a near-term goal.Audio Search - I've thought about this, and though it's interesting, I'd want to do it without including torrent search. Torrent search is very problematic. Just ask ISOHunt and similar sites. I don't want to go there."Stumbling" - I've always loved the discovery aspect of sites like StumbleUpon. I'm not yet sure how I'd be able to put an interesting spin on it, though. And, without categorization, you run into the "wall of butts" problem again. We'll eventually have to get decent machine-learning-based categorization figured out, but I'd rather do this later -- after we get regular search working pretty well.

story:
Imezing is the screwdriver set that is exquisite, smooth and easy to use. It features Apple-grade surface finishing, 10-in-1 magnetic tips storable in the cap and innovative solid one-piece body.

Carrying clean design, we think as a home / office gadget tool that DIYers and people do dis-assembly with, it may go beyond multi-functional, but can be solid, practical, stylist and comfortably fit in any space.

Screwdriver doesn’t have to be something dull and humble. As the most frequently used tool in everyday life, it should emphasize not only the usability, but the design and construction sturdiness. It can be your escort in many scenarios: your desktop tool, office / household fixing gadget for multiple tasks, DIY mechanics, etc. 

Upgrading screwdrivers to the next level, we’re bringing you an all-steel one-piece designed screwdriver set that includes 2 screwdrivers, 10 tips for each screwdriver with easy management system.

The Home Improvement Screwdriver stores 10 replacement screwdriver bits.  In this way, the entire screwdriver and replacement heads can be  perfectly combined. This convenient and space saving design reduces the  number of tools users need to carry and you won’t be worrying about  getting the bits lost from time to time.  

You won’t have to search through your tool drawer for the right size and  type screwdriver, Imezing is really handy and ready having all 10 bits  stored in the handle. 

Probably the world’s first one-piece integral molding you’ve never seen on competitive products. Imezing displays slim, smooth curves and offers super comfortable, ergonomic grip. There’s even no gap or screws in the surface, making you focus only on the fun of building / taking apart things.

Abide by the great sculptor Michelangelo’s ideology:

“The sculpture is already complete within the marble block, before I start my work. It is already there, I just have to chisel away the superfluous material.”

Our designer shaped Imezing from a solid piece of metal, with no welds, no stitching, no embedding, no cuts.  

Using German quality technology and Apple-grade anodizing process, Imezing offers exquisite touch and feel, and is resistant to staining and corrosion as well. Precision screwdrivers are great for smaller fasteners on home appliances and electronics.

The design and construction were paid much attention to achieve fine appearance and great durability.

The screwdriver bits are made of high-grade S2 alloy steel material. With CNC precision forming process, they address your demand more accurately.

 

The set contains 2 screwdrivers of different sizes and 10 bits for each that cover commonly used bits for your home, or business needs.

The Home Improvement Screwdriver (182 x 27mm / 7.2 x 1.1 inch) is ideal for tasks around the home, garage, garden and workshop. 

The Precision Screwdriver (121 x 10mm / 4.8 x 0.4 inch) is suitable for office repairs, small gear fixing like glasses or mobile phone. It comes in pen size and the premium looking makes it a stylish decoration of the office desktop.

No additional tools are needed to install the bits to the screwdriver head thanks to the magnetic design. When the bits get close, they will automatically get installed. Continuing suction ensures that bits don't loosen during use.

Magnetic bits are also very important especially on small screws: it allows you to control the screws when you’re working in tight spaces. We understand it could be quite frustrating to maneuver a screw into a position and when it drops off to inaccessible location. The magnetic tips are just here to help overcome this problem.

The internal gears are tightly set and the screwdriver body is well built, providing anti-drop, anti-stress quality. With long shaft, Imezing tackles different fastening tasks easily.

This is the perfect individual hand tool on the go: only 27mm / 10mm in diameter meaning comfortable for most people to hold. It is ideal for technicians or women to apply on computers, shelves, small coffee tables, electric fans, bicycles, skateboards, toys and crafts , etc.

Precision screwdrivers are great for smaller fasteners on home appliances and electronics.

 

 

Risks and challenges

We are very excited to bring to market the Imezing screwdriver set. We have finished the product R&D, and ready to run into testing production. The team has over 10-years product realization and is able to encounter accidental events in supply chain.

Shipping will be the greatest challenge based on global spread of the Coronavirus. Yet, we are committed to keeping you informed of our progress throughout our campaign.

In respect with the international delivery, we will be partnering with a reliable company with more than 10 years experience in international shipping to ensure efficient and safe delivery. And we'll be listening to our backers' voices and inquires at Kickstarter community, throughout any channel they may reach us, and ensure to provide prompt response.

story:
Background

Camptocamp kickstarts a new crowdfunding campaign in order to develop the Odoo Magento Connector for Odoo 8 !
We estimate that EUR 15’000.- need to be collected to start this exciting project and provide the community with a one-to-one migration development.

If we collect more than EUR 15’000.- we do have a lot of ideas to extend the features of the Odoo Magento Connector: multi-company support, synchronization jobs’ categorization for optimized performance…

Feel free to also make your own suggestions by sending an email to funding@camptocamp.com !

The Odoo Magento Connector for Odoo 8 will be based on the OpenERP Magento Connector for OpenERP 7 and will have the following core features:
  • Compatible with Odoo 8 and the latest Magento versions (1.7 or later);
  • Synchronization of customers, sales orders, invoices, payment and shipping status;
  • Multi-Websites, multi-Stores, multi-Storeviews, and even the possibility to connect several Magento instances on the same Odoo back-end;
  • Multi-Warehouses, multi-Currencies and multi-Languages;
  • Magento typology of products supported: simple, grouped and configurable products.

It is also intended to provide the public with an update on the comprehensive developer’s technical documentation aimed to help to implement the Odoo Magento Connector for Odoo 8 best.

The previous OpenERP Magento Connector for OpenERP 7 – see: www.openerp-magento-connector.com – initally required more than 60 man-days of software development to meet the demanding needs of well-established e-commerce businesses processing between 100 to 2’000 sales orders each day.
Apart from being ideally suitable for important Magento e-shops, this new-generation connector gained a huge interest among the Odoo community : hundreds of messages were exchanged between users and the supporting community of this project, and we are really proud of that !


What will be achieved with the collected funds?

  1. Migration of the Magento connector module itself (magentoerpconnect) and adaptation of the module to the updated Odoo data model;
  2. Migration of all the e-commerce modules used by the connector (connector-ecommerce, sale_automatic_workflow, sale_payment_method, product_m2m_categories, magentoerpconnect_options_active and magentoerpconnect_pricing);
  3. Update of the API;
  4. Update of the developer’s documentation;
  5. For those who were already using the OpenERP Magento Connector for OpenERP 7: availability of an additional migration routine, which will migrate your data (associated to the connector modules) from OpenERP 7 to Odoo 8.

The project's deadline is supposed to be March 31st. Once the development work will be completed, this module will remain under an Open Source license (AGPL v3).

To benefit from a great and quality module with a solid and worldwide community support, help us now to gather the needed funds to start the development of the Odoo Magento Connector for Odoo 8 !

Again, thank you so very much for your participation and support !

We adore digital calendars. They sync across all our devices and consistently keep us abreast of all our upcoming engagements.

But we also love paper planners. They have that tactile feel, and the physical act of writing improves memory retention, allowing us to make better decisions. They're a beautiful and effective way to remain both organized and productive.

At some point, we faced a dilemma - Digital Calendars vs Paper Planner. The constant switching back and forth often is neither convenient nor efficient.

Our technical background inspired us to look for new solutions using the latest technologies.

Today, we’re thrilled to share with you Slice Planner: a hybrid planning system that maintains the utmost efficiency in your workflow by marrying the worlds of physical and digital.

 

Slice Planner is a brand new hybrid approach to planning, combining an old-fashioned paper planner with a digital calendar. Powered by computer vision and augmented reality, our unique system complements your favorite digital calendars (Google, Apple and Outlook) and provides even more flexibility to your daily planning routine.

WHAT MAKES SLICE PLANNER NOTEBOOK SO SPECIAL

We approached the creation of Slice Planner with a dedication to superlative design principles.

Throughout the creative process, we examined dozens of size, functional, and material combinations to determine the best fit. We ultimately arrived at a sublime selection of premium Slice Planner notebooks in two different cover materials and a choice of four colors.

Genuine Italian leather cover available in soothing Ocean Blue and a tastefully neutral Desert Yellow. This type of soft cover provides for easy paper-insert refills, ensuring that you’ll never run out of space to jot down your thoughts.

Durable book cloth hardcover available in striking Coral Orange and elegant Steel Gray. A pleasantly robust surface texture is married to the functionality offered by the included elastic band that matches the cover color. 

 

 

 

The core pillar of our approach is the radial diagram that is reminiscent of an analog clock. We designed this to help visual thinkers (65% of the population) master their time and plan their activities in more intuitive and convenient ways. The clockface diagram helps to keep a focus on individual tasks and allows users to have a better perception of time. It does this by providing a visual display of the day, all at one glance.

The clockface diagram is similar to an analog clockface — 12 hours is the maximum capacity of what you can put into a single diagram. Our survey showed that on average, people do not plan for more than 9.5 hours per day. Moreover, it is not very efficient to commit to many things. This approach literally saves you from overworking. Need to plan for the other part of the day? No problem; simply use the next page with another diagram.

Start using the notebook any day of the year. Every clockface diagram comes undated, so you can miss a single day, two days, or even an entire week without wasting any pages.

Want to take a test drive of clockface diagram? Download and print these PDF’s:
A4 page size | Letter page size
